case_vignette:
A 50-year-old African American male with past medical history of hypertension and hypertension presents for evaluation of light spots on his legs that he initially noticed one year ago. The lesions are not painful or itchy, but he is concerned that they are increasing in frequency. When they first develop they do not significantly grow in size. He has not tried any treatments. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally. Physical examination demonstrates multiple hypopigmented ovoid macules scattered on the distal shins bilaterally.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have light spots on my legs that I first noticed a year ago.
Have these spots changed in size or multiplied over the year?
They have not significantly grown in size, but they are increasing in frequency.
Are the spots itchy or painful?
No, the spots are not painful or itchy.
Do these spots get aggravated by the sun exposure?
I didn't notice any changes related to sun exposure.
Have you had any recent infections or illnesses when you first noticed these spots?
I haven't mentioned any recent infections or illnesses when I first noticed the spots.
Do you have any family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases?
I haven't mentioned any family history of skin conditions or autoimmune diseases.
Have you been using any new medications or topical treatments that coincide with when the spots first appeared?
I have not tried any treatments for the spots.
Final Diagnosis: Idiopathic Guttate Hypomelanosis
